title: Monday, 10th October, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM

Morning

PM

Guess we can start with a chart tweeted out in the wee hours by Joe Weisenthal

PM

https://twitter.com/TheStalwart/status/785290668604329985

11:01 am
PM

Mexican peso

PM

Highest it's been for a month

PM

But I'm confused on this

11:02 am
BE

?

PM

The peso rallies on Trump avoiding meltdown?

PM

Or does a non-meltdown make a Hilary victory more likely?

11:03 am
PM

(Yeah, we're not very good US political pundits)

PM

(Or at least I'm not;. Bryce might be)

BE

We're reading US voting intentions into the USDMXN spot rate? What kind of freaky Keynesian beauty contest is this?

11:04 am
BE

I mean, really? Is this what it's come to?

PM

Yep. On the Twitter, last night, during the debate, peson seen as key live barometer

BE

............ sheesh.

11:05 am
PM

But anyway, best thing this weekend on the Trump front was this

PM
BE

Oh god.

11:05 am
PM

He's terrific

BE

Not De Niro.

PM

I loe de Niro

11:06 am
PM

How can you not?

BE

I disagree. He's not terrific. And this isn't terrific.

BE

Look -- we're at a really difficult point in politics. Really, really difficult.

11:06 am
BE

As in, this post-truth thing you keep banging on about

BE

But also, the dismalising of public discourse

BE

There's a consistent lowering of expectations for what constitutes decency.

11:07 am
PM

This is true

BE

This is what's made it somehow acceptable to talk about throwing your political opponent in jail.

BE

It's what allows bragging about sexual assaults to be excused as "locker room talk", whatever the hell that means.

11:07 am
BE

In that context, I find singularly helpful when a septuagenarian offers to punch another septuagenarian in the face.

BE

And also -- highlighting the post-truth aspect that overarches all this -- I'm really keen on quasi-political messages being delivered by actors playing up to their typecasting.

BE

It's as if Leonard Nemoy claimed to be an actual Vulcan to announce: "Logically, a vote for Trump helps you live long and prosper".

11:08 am
BE

Except it's ten times worse.

BE

None of this moves us out of the gutter. Not even an inch.

PM

It's America, Bryce

11:08 am
BE

So, no. Not terrific. Unhelpful. But we can disagree, as we often do.

undefined
PM

And so to the Nobel for Economics

11:08 am
PM

Sorry, the Sveriges Riksbank Prize in memory of Alfred Nobel

BE

Oh, great. Did I win? Because it's about time I had some recognition.

PM

Nope not this time

11:09 am
PM

It's Oliver Hart

PM

PM

And Bengt Holmström

11:09 am
PM

Whose pic ive lost. sorry

BE

Oh, Bengt Holmström. Cool.

PM

Hart's a sort of Brit

11:10 am
PM

Born here, but now an American citizen

PM

Would Ms May allow him to advise the government, I wonder

PM

Does he count as "British"

11:10 am
PM

Who knows

undefined
PM

So how are equity markets taking all this?

11:12 am
BE

Oh, here we go then. FTSE's flatish to up providing you put it in our developing-market currency.

BE

11 points at 7055 at pixel.

PM

hmm

11:12 am
BE

Though at its lowest since July in dollars

BE

And in euros

BE

And in Norwegian krone

11:12 am
BE

And in Hong Kong dollars

BE

Polish Zloty? Lowest since July.

BE

Indonesian Rupiah? Lowest since July.

11:13 am
BE

I could show you the charts of all these, but won't, because I suspect readers are bored of the theme.

BE

In terms of news, the big news on the tape is William Hill.

William Hill PLC (WMH:LSE): Last: 299.97, up 5.37 (+1.82%), High: 313.65, Low: 297.90, Volume: 8.20m
11:14 am
PM

Yeah, they'r e really trying to do this

BE

Seems so. Proposing a reverse take-over of Amaya, though it's calling it a merger of equals.

PM

A nil-premium merger of equals no less

11:14 am
BE

Which is clearly nonsense. William Hill is £2.7bn cap, Amaya's £3.1bn

BE

Amaya debt is £1.94bn vs William Hill debt £586m

PM

Ouch

11:15 am
BE

That's one curious aspect about this

BE

(@Flaneur: Mackintosh used to talk a lot about FTSE in gold, but he's gone elsewhere now so we miss the daily reminders.)

BE

Another relates to Rafi Ashkenazi, Amaya's very recently appointed CEO

11:16 am
BE

Who we assume would get the CEO job of the combined group

BE

He's formerly COO of Playtech, which probably not coincidentally was William Hill's former JV partner.

PM

But it would be london listed, right?

11:17 am
BE

Yep.

BE

The third, and most curious to me, aspect here is unregulated markets.

BE

About a quarter of Amaya's revenue's from unregulated territories such as Russia.

11:18 am
PM

So, to simplify, this deal bring more operational risk and more leverage for William Hill. And that's it

PM

regulatory risk

BE

And that 25%, of course, is an estimate. It's not particularly difficult to game your online location.

11:18 am
BE

Note also that Amaya is nearly all poker and casino

BE

Poker is 75% of its total revenues, casino 21%. Sports betting's the stub.

BE

Now -- how can I phrase this uncontroversially? -- I've heard stories about poker tables being used as an organised way to pass money from one jurisdiction to another.

11:19 am
PM

Money laundering?

BE

I didn't say that. I was careful not to say that.

PM

Oh

11:20 am
BE

Now traditionally, William Hill has not liked unregulated markets.

BE

You'll remember the Sportingbet deal, from way back when, that required GVC to take the unregulated stuff.

BE

And recent WMH proposals have tended to follow similar structures. This is a real about-turn in terms of strategy.

11:22 am
BE

I don't know why we're all so chilled about unregulated gambling markets these days. Possibly New Jersey approving Pokerstars earlier in the year, but that's not really symbolic of anything I'd suggest.

BE

Finally, any mention of Amaya needs to note its rather lively past

BE

Which isn't entirely buried.

11:23 am
BE

As in, its businesses operating illegally in the US for five years to 2011, and settling with the DOJ a year later for $731m.

BE

And former CEO David Baazov getting charged with insider trading, then leaving in August

BE

But more importantly there's the state settlement risk.

11:23 am
BE

As in, the state of Kentucky successfully sued Amaya to recover losses while Pokerstars was operating illegally in the state.

BE

The judge guessed at a loss of -- get this! -- $290m

PM

For one state?

11:24 am
BE

Yep. And then tripled it to award damages.

BE

$870m

PM

Blimey

11:24 am
BE

Amaya is appealing. They'd rather pay $18m, rather than $870m.

PM

This looks like a new approach to your old specialism of 'un-deal making'

PM

Un-rainmaker

11:25 am
BE

Heh.

BE

Scoops are proving rather elusive pre news these days, for various reasons, so I guess we can do what we can to derail deals post news.

BE

So anyway, I feel I've typed enough here. Have a more measured view from an expert.

11:00 am
PM

Welcome to Markets Live

BE

The news that William Hill and Amaya are currently in advanced talks about a possible merger is surprising for a number of reasons.
Firstly, there is the timing. William Hill faces an imminent regulatory review of betting machines in its shops, which could have a material impact on its future earnings stream. How a potential merger partner could be comfortable with the valuation of the business ahead of such a review is difficult to see. By the same token, Amaya is currently appealing a case taken by the state of Kentucky last year which resulted in a potential fine for the company of $870m (£696m). While it is likely (in our untrained legal view) that this will be reduced on appeal, it is nonetheless a very material sum in the context of a £5.7bn merger.

BE

Secondly, a merger with Amaya would represent a significant change of approach by the William Hill board in at least two respects: financial leverage and its comfort levels with unregulated market exposure. With respect to financial leverage, the merger would involve the combined group running with a higher level of debt for a period of time than the William Hill board has historically been comfortable with (net debt/EBITDA of 3.6-3.8x). Ordinarily, gearing up the balance sheet at this point in the regulatory (and economic) cycle would be highly unusual. In addition, nearly two-thirds of the group’s debt would be dollar-denominated (at least initially) which would have to be a consideration against the backdrop of more volatile currency markets.
The transaction would also signal a willingness on the part of the board to materially increase the proportion of its revenues and earnings coming from unregulated online gaming markets.

11:27 am
BE

The group’s share of revenues coming from unregulated markets would increase from less than 4% today to 25% post-merger. The percentage of group earnings coming from these markets would be higher again given the higher profit margins achieved there.
All that said, there is of course some strategic merit to this deal. For a start, the combined entity would have diversified scale. Its 2015 earnings base (of nearly £700m in EBITDA) would be 40% higher than our 2017 forecast for Paddy Power Betfair for example. And that’s before £100m+ in likely cost synergies are considered. Secondly, exposure to UK regulatory risk would be materially reduced. Thirdly, aside from the UK, no individual market would account for more than 5% of group revenues and the business would be 60% online, achieving one of the goals of the William Hill board. The final financial terms of the transaction could also be attractive given that Amaya is currently more profitable than William Hill. William Hill’s search for an experienced digital CEO would be concluded.
Whether these benefits justify the additional risk that such a merger would bring remains to be seen. We are open-minded but very much yet to be convinced.

BE

And UBS.

BE

We believe the potential deal with Amaya is in line with William Hill's strategy to diversify through international expansion, and to drive growth in the online business. We estimate that the combined group would have 40-50% of its revenues from international (vs c15% currently for WMH), and 65% of its revenues from digital (currently c40%). We see the brand/product portfolios as complementary, with WMH strong in sports, and Amaya strong in Poker, with a fast growing Casino business. In terms of synergies, we think c£100m is a good 'starting point' based on other deals in the industry, but we flex this number in our model.

11:27 am
BE

Our main concern of such a deal is the leverage the combined group would likely have. We estimate pro-forma Net Debt / EBITDA of c3.5x, which we view as high in light of regulatory risks in the UK. Such a deal would give William Hill significant exposure to the Poker industry, which is not growing as quickly as online sports betting (roughly flat vs sports betting greater than 10% per year). William Hill will also need to analyse the situation with the state of Kentucky seeking damages of c$870m from Amaya. Finally, the recent devaluation of the GBP makes such a deal more expensive vs previously.

BE

We expect WMH shares will be up strongly on Monday, but we believe we need more information, particularly regarding synergies, in order to accurately assess the merits of such a deal for William Hill shareholders. Our price target is based on a multiple-based SOTP with a blended EV/EBITDA multiple of 9.4x.

BE

...... not so much "strongly" as it turns out.

11:28 am
William Hill PLC (WMH:LSE): Last: 300.10, up 5.5 (+1.87%), High: 313.65, Low: 297.90, Volume: 8.27m
BE

Underperforming the sector, in fact.

Ladbrokes PLC (LAD:LSE): Last: 137.31, up 3.71 (+2.78%), High: 139.50, Low: 135.70, Volume: 4.89m
11:28 am
GVC Holdings PLC (GVC:LSE): Last: 765.50, up 15 (+2.00%), High: 768.50, Low: 750.00, Volume: 319.28k
PM

ha

BE

Which is partly on a push from Deutsche Bank, with slightly unfortunate timing.

11:29 am
PM

Goodness, they have 120 pages out on the sector

BE

Yep, imagine doing 120 pages then William Hill drops a reverse takeover on the day you get it through compliance?

BE

Poor Mr Wheatcroft. It must've taken him months.

11:31 am
BE

(I assume Wheatcroft. The PDF's too big for my computer to open in a hurry.)

PM

(it is Wheatcroft - and Anand Date )

BE

Cool. Here's the upshot.

11:31 am
BE

Main conclusions: overall positive outlook
1) Gaming markets are large and growing, especially online; 2) Sentiment
towards unregulated jurisdiction is warming up, especially where market risk is
diversified; 3) Regulatory clarity is gradually emerging in multiple jurisdictions
which should drive a re-rating to offset tax impacts; 4) We anticipate further
online consolidation as scale drives material financial and operational benefits;
5) Online business models are financially attractive and highly cash generative;
6) We are slightly more cautious around UK retail regulation and online
cannibalisation; 7) Premium ratings are likely for companies that show growth,
strong cash generation and diversification of regulatory risk.

BE

Our top picks: William Hill and Playtech
We initiate coverage with a Buy on Paddy Power Betfair (price target 10,500p,
20% upside), Buy on Playtech (PT 1,175p, 24%) and Buy on GVC (PT 850p,
13%). We reiterate our Buy on William Hill (PT 390p, 26%) and upgrade
Ladbrokes to Buy (PT 170p, 19%), with estimates now including the Coral
merger. Due to a change in team structure, we transfer coverage of Ladbrokes
from Anand Date to James Wheatcroft with immediate effect.

BE

DB Blue Sky scenarios highlight growth and cash generation
We model various scenarios for each company including: the powerful
combination of compounding revenue growth and operational leverage; more
efficient balance sheets via potential acquisitions and share buybacks; and,
further re-rating potential as online exposure grows.

11:32 am
BE

Risk
Regulatory and tax risk is ever-present in the gaming sector. The threat to UK
retail is temporarily heightened as we await the pending Triennial Review for
gaming machines. Large-scale online operators should be better placed to
absorb any additional cost burden.

BE

You get the idea.

undefined
11:41 am
PM

Corporate news actually v thin today, bar William Hill

PM

BE

Yeah, there ain't much around. We can have a whip through sellside if it helps pass the time.

11:42 am
BE

EasyJet, for instance. One-year low.

easyJet plc (EZJ:LSE): Last: 878.00, down 18 (-2.01%), High: 895.50, Low: 862.56, Volume: 2.07m
BE

Which prompted me to check something, just for my own interest ......

11:43 am
BE

Easyjet shares (green) vs Ryanair (white), normalised to the start of McCall's tenure

BE

BE

Underperforming for about 18 months now.

11:44 am
BE

Dunno how long until shareholders begin to get itchy, given seven years is usually a pretty good shift for a CEO irrespective of performance.

BE

Anyway, SocGen downgrades this morning.

BE

We think the factors burdening EZY in FY16 will persist or even intensify:
1) the GBP is now trading at a 30-year low vs the USD, which will
gradually inflate EZY’s fuel bill, with hedging contracts expiring; 2) the
GBP has also fallen against the EUR, making holidays on the continent
more expensive; and (3) political uncertainties and terror risk are unlikely
to disappear quickly. We expect further earnings declines in FY17e and
FY18e and cut our EPS by 25%. Downgrade to Sell, new TP 820p.

11:45 am
BE

Substantial headwinds still to come: EasyJet faces substantial headwinds over the next 24 months in our view: post Brexit the UK economy will grow softly (SG GDP forecast +0.7% in 17e, +0.5% in 18e) which will likely result in soft demand. The GBP’s weakness will have a double negative effect: it will burden UK outbound tourism (which we estimate AF FP represents some 2/3 of EZY’s UK capacity) as holidays become more expensive.

BE

Fuel bill to be inflated by weak GBP: The weaker GBP will also drive up EZY’s fuel bill, as the GBP is now at a 30Y low vs the USD; due to hedging, the latter effect will only gradually unfold over the upcoming 24 months. EZY’s fuel bill is currently c.£1bn, meaning that every 1% of GBP weakening vs the USD pushes the fuel bill up roughly £10m with a two-year delay. The current year is 74% hedged at a GBP/USD rate of 1.52, but with a two-year time lag we expect an effective rate close to 1.30.

PM

So first you try and un-merge William Hill's plans; now you are trying to unseat Ms McCall. I don't know.

11:48 am
BE

........ I'm not! I'm not doing anything of the sort! I'm just noting that many of EasyJet's problems seem to be operational in nature, as we've been saying for at least a year.

PM

Dunno how long until shareholders begin to get itchy, given seven years is usually a pretty good shift for a CEO irrespective of performance.

BE

And by memory, Ms McCall gets about £7m a year to make sure EasyJet's problems aren't operational in nature.

11:50 am
BE

I dunno. If I were a shareholder, I'd be asking questions. But I'm not. I'm just the chump stuck at some one-shed out-of-town airport because my flight missed its slot out of Luton and is running four hours late.

undefined

PM

omg smile

PM

https://www.ft.com.../Exclusive/product

PM

But the Financial Times has learnt that Deutsche’s result was boosted by a special concession agreed by its supervisor, the European Central Bank.

Deutsche’s results included the $4bn proceeds from selling its stake in Chinese lender Hua Xia even though the deal had not been done by the end of 2015, the official cut-off point for transactions to be included.

The Hua Xia sale was agreed in December 2015. It has still not been completed and now faces a delay after missing a regulatory deadline last month, though the bank is still confident of completion this year.

11:52 am

BE

undefined
BE

Apologies to those mentioning smallcaps on the right, I've not been through them this morning.

11:56 am
BE

Having said that, we haven't mentioned Mitie.

Mitie Group PLC (MTO:LSE): Last: 194.50, up 0.4 (+0.21%), High: 203.40, Low: 194.00, Volume: 879.19k
BE

Soaring 0.2% on a new CEO.

11:57 am
PM

Phil Bentley

BE

Yup, Phil Bentley -- who was dumped from C&W when Liberty bought it -- to replace Ruby McGregor-Smith

PM

11:58 am
BE

He's an accountant -- something Mitie has perhaps needed -- and has spent time also at British Gas, Centrica, Diageo and BP

BE

RBC sounds happyish.

BE

After the last warning, it is likely to be seen as positive news that an outsider is coming in at last, although we suspect there will be some trepidation in the market that there will be a further rebasing of the balance sheet/forecasts. He joins on 1 November so suspect won’t get much from him strategically until H1 numbers in May. These are clearly challenging times for the group in what is a very tough UK market, but this looks to us to be a good move.

11:58 am
BE

Canaccord too.

BE

In light of last month's profit warning, which was driven by material delays in project related work in H1, the timing of this announcement is likely to create some uncertainty, with management change in the sector often a catalyst for further issues to be identified.

Whilst any further impact remains unknown, the short term issues driven by budgetary pressures from the National Living Wage (NLW) and customer spending uncertainty following the EU referendum has been announced and much of the identified cost savings program, which underpins our current estimates, is already underway

With interim results anticipated to be announced on the 21st of November we expect Phil Bentley to be involved in the process and believe that some of the legacy concerns, such as the Group's Healthcare goodwill, may well be addressed at that time, offering new management the opportunity to start with a cleaner slate

BE

Whilst the industry backdrop remains tough for project related spend given macro uncertainty and staff cost inflation, Mitie's market position leaves it better positioned than many to absorb the impact. With the Group operating in a fragmented market which seems set to undergo significant change, there will undoubtedly be some bumps in the short term but the Group is arguably better positioned than smaller rivals to drive change in service delivery (with the introduction of more technology led solutions and/or a change in contract structure). As such, it could see opportunities as both the public and private sector seek cost savings and transformation in the current environment.

Following the warning last month the shares have fallen to a +12m PE of 8.6x, in line with the the historic lower bound of c9x over the past 10 yrs and the longer term average of 12x, which remains the basis of our target price.
